an10.18:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an10.18:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an10.18:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an10.18:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should live with a protector, not without one.

an10.18:2.2.eng: Living without a protector is suffering.

an10.18:2.3.eng: There are ten qualities that serve as protector.

an10.18:2.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an10.18:2.5.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an10.18:2.6.pli: ‘Sīlavā vatāyaṃ bhikkhu pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesū’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:2.6.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:2.7.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:2.7.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:2.8.eng: This is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an10.18:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an10.18:3.2.pli: ‘Bahussuto vatāyaṃ bhikkhu sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:3.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:3.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:3.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:3.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
an10.18:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.

an10.18:4.2.pli: ‘Kalyāṇamitto vatāyaṃ bhikkhu kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:4.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:4.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:4.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:4.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato, khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṃ.
an10.18:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.

an10.18:5.2.pli: ‘Suvaco vatāyaṃ bhikkhu sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato, khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsanin’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:5.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:5.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:5.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:5.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṃ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni, tattha dakkho hoti analaso, tatrūpāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgato, alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ.
an10.18:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.

an10.18:6.2.pli: ‘Yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṃ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni, tattha dakkho vatāyaṃ bhikkhu analaso, tatrūpāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgato, alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātun’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:6.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:6.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:6.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:6.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro, abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.
an10.18:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.

an10.18:7.2.pli: ‘Dhammakāmo vatāyaṃ bhikkhu piyasamudāhāro, abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:7.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:7.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:7.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:7.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu ‘āraddhavīriyo vatāyaṃ bhikkhu viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesū’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū …
an10.18:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an10.18:8.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:8.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:8.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:8.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītaracīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena.
an10.18:9.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an10.18:9.2.pli: ‘Santuṭṭho vatāyaṃ bhikkhu itarītaracīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārenā’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:9.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:9.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:9.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:9.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
an10.18:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

an10.18:10.2.pli: ‘Satimā vatāyaṃ bhikkhu paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:10.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:10.3.pli: Tassa therānukampitassa majjhimānukampitassa navānukampitassa vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
an10.18:10.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:10.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an10.18:11.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an10.18:11.2.pli: ‘Paññavā vatāyaṃ bhikkhu udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā’ti therāpi naṃ bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an10.18:11.2.eng: Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing.

an10.18:11.3.eng: Being treated with such kindness by the senior, middle, and junior mendicants, that mendicant can expect only growth, not decline.

an10.18:11.4.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.18:12.1.eng: You should live with a protector, not without one.

an10.18:12.2.eng: Living without a protector is suffering.

an10.18:12.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa nāthakaraṇā dhammā”ti.
an10.18:12.3.eng: These are the ten qualities that serve as protector.”

an10.18:12.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an10.18:12.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
an10.18:12.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

an10.180:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the skillful and the unskillful …

an10.181:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the beneficial and the harmful. …

an10.182:1.1.eng: “I will teach you what is the teaching and what is not the teaching. …

an10.182:1.3.eng: And what is not the teaching?

an10.182:1.6.eng: This is called what is not the teaching.

an10.183:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the defiled principle and the undefiled. …

an10.183:1.3.eng: And what is the defiled principle?

an10.183:1.6.eng: This is called the defiled principle.

an10.183:2.1.eng: And what is the undefiled principle?

an10.183:2.4.eng: This is called the undefiled principle.”

an10.184:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the blameworthy principle and the blameless. …

an10.184:1.3.eng: And what is the blameworthy principle?

an10.184:1.6.eng: This is called the blameworthy principle.

an10.184:2.1.eng: And what is the blameless principle?

an10.184:2.4.eng: This is called the blameless principle.”

an10.185:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the mortifying principle and the unmortifying. …

an10.185:1.3.eng: And what is the mortifying principle?

an10.185:1.6.eng: This is called the mortifying principle.

an10.185:2.1.eng: And what is the unmortifying principle?

an10.185:2.4.eng: This is called the unmortifying principle.”

an10.186:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle that leads to accumulation and that which leads to dispersal. …

an10.186:1.3.eng: And what is the principle that leads to accumulation?

an10.186:1.6.eng: This is called the principle that leads to accumulation.

an10.186:2.1.eng: And what is the principle that leads to dispersal?

an10.186:2.4.eng: This is called the principle that leads to dispersal.”

an10.187:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle that has suffering as outcome, and that which has happiness as outcome. …

an10.187:1.3.eng: And what is the principle whose outcome is suffering?

an10.187:1.6.eng: This is the principle whose outcome is suffering.

an10.187:2.1.eng: And what is the principle whose outcome is happiness?

an10.187:2.4.eng: This is the principle whose outcome is happiness.”

an10.188:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle that results in suffering and that which results in happiness. …

an10.188:1.3.eng: And what is the principle that results in suffering?

an10.188:1.6.eng: This is called the principle that results in suffering.

an10.188:2.1.eng: And what is the principle that results in happiness?

an10.188:2.4.eng: This is called the principle that results in happiness.”

an10.189:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the noble path and the ignoble path. …

an10.189:1.3.eng: And what is the ignoble path?

an10.189:1.6.eng: This is called the ignoble path.

an10.189:2.1.eng: And what is the noble path?

an10.189:2.4.eng: This is called the noble path.”

an10.19:1.1.pli: “Dasayime, bhikkhave, ariyāvāsā, ye ariyā āvasiṃsu vā āvasanti vā āvasissanti vā.
an10.19:1.1.eng: “There are these ten abodes of the noble ones in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.

an10.19:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti, chaḷaṅgasamannāgato, ekārakkho, caturāpasseno, paṇunnapaccekasacco, samavayasaṭṭhesano, anāvilasaṅkappo, passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro, suvimuttacitto, suvimuttapañño.
an10.19:1.3.eng: A mendicant has given up five factors, is endowed with six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has pure intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.

an10.19:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa ariyāvāsā, ye ariyā āvasiṃsu vā āvasanti vā āvasissanti vā”ti.
an10.19:1.4.eng: These are the ten abodes of the noble ones in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.”

an10.190:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the dark path and the bright path. …

an10.190:1.3.eng: And what is the dark path?

an10.190:1.6.eng: This is called the dark path.

an10.190:2.1.eng: And what is the bright path?

an10.190:2.4.eng: This is called the bright path.”

an10.191:1.1.eng: “I will teach you what is the true teaching and what is not the true teaching. …

an10.191:1.3.eng: And what is not the true teaching?

an10.191:1.6.eng: This is called what is not the true teaching.

an10.191:2.1.eng: And what is the true teaching?

an10.191:2.4.eng: This is called the true teaching.”

an10.192:0.3.eng: The Teaching of the True Persons

an10.192:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the teaching of the true persons and the teaching of the untrue persons.

an10.192:1.3.eng: And what is the teaching of the untrue persons?

an10.192:1.6.eng: This is the teaching of the untrue persons.

an10.192:2.1.eng: And what is the teaching of the true persons?

an10.192:2.4.eng: This is the teaching of the true persons.”

an10.193:1.1.pli: “Uppādetabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na uppādetabbañca.
an10.193:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to activate and the principle not to activate. …

an10.193:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na uppādetabbo dhammo?
an10.193:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to activate?

an10.193:1.6.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na uppādetabbo dhammo.
an10.193:1.6.eng: This is called the principle not to activate.

an10.193:2.1.eng: And what is the principle to activate?

an10.193:2.4.eng: This is called the principle to activate.”

an10.194:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to cultivate and the principle not to cultivate. …

an10.194:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to cultivate?

an10.194:1.6.eng: This is called the principle not to cultivate.

an10.194:2.1.eng: And what is the principle to cultivate?

an10.194:2.4.eng: This is called the principle to cultivate.”

an10.195:1.1.pli: “Bhāvetabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na bhāvetabbañca.
an10.195:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to develop and the principle not to develop. …

an10.195:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.

an10.195:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na bhāvetabbo dhammo?
an10.195:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to develop?

an10.195:1.6.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na bhāvetabbo dhammo.
an10.195:1.6.eng: This is called the principle not to develop.

an10.195:2.1.eng: And what is the principle to develop?

an10.195:2.4.eng: This is called the principle to develop.”

an10.196:0.3.eng: Principles That Should Be Made Much Of

an10.196:1.1.pli: “Bahulīkātabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na bahulīkātabbañca.
an10.196:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to make much of and the principle not to make much of. …

an10.196:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na bahulīkātabbo dhammo?
an10.196:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to make much of?

an10.196:1.6.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na bahulīkātabbo dhammo.
an10.196:1.6.eng: This is called the principle not to make much of.

an10.196:2.1.eng: And what is the principle to make much of?

an10.196:2.4.eng: This is called the principle to make much of.”

an10.197:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to recollect and the principle not to recollect. …

an10.197:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to recollect?

an10.197:1.6.eng: This is called the principle not to recollect.

an10.197:2.1.eng: And what is the principle to recollect?

an10.197:2.4.eng: This is called the principle to recollect.”

an10.198:1.1.pli: “Sacchikātabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na sacchikātabbañca.
an10.198:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to realize and the principle not to realize. …

an10.198:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na sacchikātabbo dhammo?
an10.198:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to realize?

an10.198:1.6.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na sacchikātabbo dhammo.
an10.198:1.6.eng: This is called the principle not to realize.

an10.198:2.1.eng: And what is the principle to realize?

an10.198:2.4.eng: This is called the principle to realize.”
